Title: Randomised Controlled Trial of Cryoneurolysis for Phantom Limb Pain

Background: Phantom limb pain following amputation is challenging to treat. This study assessed the effectiveness of cryoneurolysis in reducing phantom pain.

Methods: Conducted at a tertiary care center, this randomised controlled trial included patients with lower-limb amputation and established phantom pain. Participants received a single-injection femoral and sciatic nerve block with lidocaine and were randomised to either ultrasound-guided percutaneous cryoneurolysis or sham treatment. The primary outcome was the change in average phantom pain intensity from baseline to 4 months, measured using a Numeric Rating Scale (0–10). Randomisation was computer-generated, and allocation was concealed. Blinding was maintained for investigators, participants, and clinical staff, except for the treating physician.

Results: A total of 144 participants were randomised: 71 to cryoneurolysis and 73 to sham. Pain intensity decreased by 0.5 [−0.5, 3.0] in the cryoneurolysis group versus 0 [0, 3] in the sham group, with an estimated difference of −0.1 (95% CI −1.0, 0.7), P=0.759. One serious adverse event occurred in the cryoneurolysis group due to a protocol deviation, resulting in quadriceps weakness and possibly a fall and clavicle fracture.

Interpretation: Cryoneurolysis did not significantly reduce phantom limb pain at 4 months. The results are specific to the study protocol, and further research is warranted to determine optimal treatment parameters such as freeze duration and anatomic location.
